messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Laminations and tekkotsu
messages.msgSnippet: Hmmm.  Just ruminating. The laminations are I think the blade equivalent of kizu - ware - and ideally shouldn t be there.  Bones I have no idea about
messages.messageBody:
Hmmm. Just ruminating. The laminations are I think the blade equivalent of
kizu - ware - and ideally shouldn't be there. "Bones" I have no idea about
although I think they are small lumps of higher carbon content = harder steel,
so they should stand proud of the surface, like currants in a bun. Your third
pic is difficult because it looks to me like an "ordinary" rusted surface where
the high bits are only high because of the corrosion pits leave them standing.
Do they look like different steel??? Thus draineth my pitiful knowledge...

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Saturday, April 02, 2005 10:16 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Laminations and tekkotsu


All, I was wondering how common visible Laminations and tekkotsu were in
older Choshu tsuba. I have a new piece, that I believe shows clear
Tekkotsu and also lamination in the mimi.

messages.subject: Laminations and tekkotsu
messages.msgSnippet: All, I was wondering how common visible Laminations and tekkotsu were in older Choshu tsuba. I have a new piece, that I believe shows clear Tekkotsu and also
messages.messageBody:
All, I was wondering how common visible Laminations and tekkotsu were in
older Choshu tsuba. I have a new piece, that I believe shows clear
Tekkotsu and also lamination in the mimi.

The images that follow ( sorry for the poor quality, I will try to get
better ones this weekend ) are attempting to show what I am referring
to. This first image looks like a lamination showing, and a small dent
around the area in question.
http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/Choshu_Kawaji/mimi-1.jpg

This image is another lamination showing in another section of the mimi.
http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/Choshu_Kawaji/mimi-3.jpg

This section, I am trying to show what looks like running bones, but
again, my photography skills fail me. Basically, through the highlite
area, there is a bone running on the diagonal.
http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/Choshu_Kawaji/mimi-2.jpg

So, is this common for Choshu works, or is it is un common ?????. I
believe the better works were from the earlier periods, though I am sure
there are some excellent examples from the last smiths as well.

Cheers

Rich
//

messages.subject: Crass Commercial Message
messages.msgSnippet: All, through one of my contacts in Japan, I am able to offer some excellent Kodogu and Inrou boxes for sale. These deluxe boxes were hand crafted by a master
messages.messageBody:
All, through one of my contacts in Japan, I am able to offer some
excellent Kodogu and Inrou boxes for sale. These deluxe boxes were hand
crafted by a master Japanese Togi, since passed away and are being
offered for sale by his wife.

The boxes are made from Ichii-Wood and are lined in quality silk and
have silk pillows. The Deluxe Lacquer boxes are made from Akita-Sugi (
Japanese Pine, grew in Akita Prefecture ) and lacquered with Japanese
Shun-Kei-Nuri.

Please have a look and contact me if you would like any more information
or to order one. Their numbers are limited.

Cheers and thanks for the band width.

Rich Turner

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/sale/Kodogu_Boxes/Kodogu_Boxes.html


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Need tsuba gurus
messages.msgSnippet: Hello Group... I have several tsuba I am trying to understand.  I am a newcomer to the tsuba and have very little research material.  In other words, I know
messages.messageBody:
Hello Group...

I have several tsuba I am trying to understand. I am a newcomer to
the tsuba and have very little research material. In other words, I
know very little. What I really need to know is are they good or bad
- what is their value if any.

The tsuba can be viewed at http://www.geocities.com/tsuba4sale/

If this is an inappropriate question for this group I apologize. I
really have no resources nearby who can help me. Several antique
dealers have made offers but I just don't know enough [I know they are
tsuba but thats it]. I have no use for them as I already have enough
stuff.


Thank you in advance....

tsuba4sale
